ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: Timepoint/visit label
Notes: e.g., Baseline, 6-Month Follow Up, Year 2; Morning, At Bedtime

ElementDescription: Race/Ethnicity: Please check all the choices below that apply to you. Hispanic
Notes: 0=No; 1=Yes

ElementDescription: Race of study subject
ValueRange: American Indian/Alaska Native; Asian; Hawaiian or Pacific Islander; Black or African American; White; More than one race; Unknown or not reported; Other Non-White; Other

ElementDescription: Racial Background: Description of Other
What is your marital status?
Notes: 1=Single, never married; 2=Married or remarried; 3=Divorced; 4=Separated; 5=Widowed; 6= Missing

ElementDescription: How many years of education did you complete?
Notes: 6=Graduated from elementary school; 12=Graduated from high school; 13=Completed 1 year of college; 15=Completed 3 years of college

ElementDescription: What is your current salary, before taxes?
How many years have you been a law enforcement officer?
How many hours of training were dedicated to mental illnesses during your initial law enforcement academy?
What is your rank?
Which of the following best describes your usual job?
Notes: 1=Vehicle patrol; 2=Foot patrol; 3=Bicycle patrol; 4=Detective/Investigator; 5=Other

ElementDescription: Please specify
Notes: Show the field ONLY if usual_job='5'

ElementDescription: What shift do you usually work?
Notes: 1=Days; 2=Afternoons; 3=Nights; 4=Two or more of the above responses were given

ElementDescription: How much exposure have you had to Crisis Intervention Team (CIT) officers over the past 2 years?
Notes: 1=No interaction with CIT officers; 2=Up to 4 hours per week, on average; 3=4-20 hours per week, on average; 4=>20 hours per week, on average

ElementDescription: Over the past 2 years have you had any training related to mental illnesses?
Notes: 0=No; 1=Yes

ElementDescription: Please describe your training over the past two years
Notes: Show the field ONLY if law_enforcement_training ='1'

ElementDescription: Have you received Crisis Negotiation training or Hostage Negotiation training?
Notes: 0=No; 1=Yes

ElementDescription: Please list the number of hours of Negotiator training received
Notes: Show the field ONLY if law_enforcement_crisis_negotiation = '1'

ElementDescription: Have you received training in interviewing and interrogation?
Notes: 0=No; 1=Yes

ElementDescription: Please list the number of hours of interviewing/interrogation training received: hours
Are you currently serving as a Negotiator (Crisis or Hostage) in your department?
Notes: 0=No; 1=Yes

ElementDescription: Are you currently on a SWAT team?
Notes: 0=No; 1=Yes

ElementDescription: Have any of your family members ever received or are they currently receiving treatment for a mental health problem (such as therapy, counseling, or medicine for mental or emotional problems)?
Notes: 0=No; 1=Yes

ElementDescription: Have you known someone within your circle of friends who has been or is currently receiving treatment for a mental health problem (such as therapy, counseling, or medicine for mental or emotional problems)?
Notes: 0=No; 1=Yes

ElementDescription: Have you ever received or are you currently receiving treatment for a mental health problem (such as therapy, counseling, or medicine for mental or emotional problems)?
Notes: 0=No; 1=Yes

ElementDescription: Have you or any members of your family or any of your friends been active as either a professional or volunteer helper in the field of counseling, therapy, psychiatry, psychology, or social work?
Notes: 0=No; 1=Yes

ElementDescription: I am interested in assisting people with mental illnesses as part of my work duties
Notes: 0=Strongly disagree; 1=Disagree; 2=Neither disagree nor agree; 3=Agree; 4=Strongly agree

Notes: 0=Strongly disagree; 1=Disagree; 2=Neither disagree nor agree; 3=Agree; 4=Strongly agree

Notes: 0=Strongly disagree; 1=Disagree; 2=Neither disagree nor agree; 3=Agree; 4=Strongly agree

Notes: 0=Strongly disagree; 1=Disagree; 2=Neither disagree nor agree; 3=Agree; 4=Strongly agree

Notes: 0=Strongly disagree; 1=Disagree; 2=Neither disagree nor agree; 3=Agree; 4=Strongly agree

ElementDescription: I am interested in crisis intervention for people with intellectual or developmental disabilities as part of my work duties
Notes: 0=Strongly disagree; 1=Disagree; 2=Neither disagree nor agree; 3=Agree; 4=Strongly agree

ElementDescription: On a scale of 1 to 10, how much do you want to be a CIT Officer? Please place a check at your level of interest
Notes: 1=Not at all interested; 10=Very interested

ElementDescription: Some people with obsessive-compulsive disorder may benefit from which of the following?
Notes: 1=Developing new hobbies; 2=Dietary counseling; 3=Legal restraining orders; 4=Limiting social contacts; 5=Support groups

ElementDescription: A 76-year-old man has mild memory problems, difficulty maintaining his house, an some confusion about which month it is. Which of the following resources may be most beneficial to him?
Notes: 1=Assisted living facility; 2=Nursing home; 3=Outpatient psychotherapy; 4=Physical exercise counseling; 5=Rehabilitation hospital

ElementDescription: A 19-year-old begins to hear voices and act paranoid several months after graduating from high school. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these problems?
Notes: 1=Excessive worries about other people's intentions; 2=Genetic tendency toward developing an illnesses; 3=Increasing use of alcohol during adolescence; 4=Not enough support from parents; 5=Stress of graduating from high school

ElementDescription: Which of the following community services is especially important for people with dementia and their families?
Notes: 1=Detoxification programs for those with alcohol abuse; 2=Hygiene programs for those with grooming problems; 3=Memory retrieval programs for those with memory loss; 4=Re-orientation programs for those who are disoriented; 5=Safe return programs for those who become lost

ElementDescription: A man is evaluated by a psychiatrist, who tells him that psychotherapy is much more important for his problems than any medications. Which of the following disorders is he most likely being seen for?
Notes: 1=Bipolar disorder; 2=Dependent personality disorder; 3=Dyslexia; 4=Heroin withdrawal; 5=Paranoid schizophrenia

ElementDescription: People who have had an episode of major depression are at most risk for which of the following?
Notes: 1=Becoming addicted to anti-depressant medicines; 2=Being diagnosed with migraines; 3=Developing schizophrenia; 4=Experiencing flashbacks about their depression; 5=Having another episode of depression

ElementDescription: Psychotherapy may be the most beneficial resource for which of the following condition?
Notes: 1=Alcohol withdrawal; 2=Cognitive disorders; 3=Developmental disorders; 4=Learning disorders; 5=Personality disorders

ElementDescription: Which of the following is a feature of all developmental disabilities?
Notes: 1=Difficulties walking; 2=Impairment in daily functioning; 3=Inability to communicate verbally; 4=Intellectual disability; 5=Unusual body appearance

ElementDescription: Which of the following is most true of psychiatric medicines for children?
Notes: 1=They are helpful for all psychiatric disorders; 2=They are often crushed and mixed in food; 3=They improve some types of symptoms; 4=They require a signature from both parents; 5=They should only be used after puberty

ElementDescription: A woman sees a therapist weekly to work on her maladaptive patterns of behavior which have repeatedly interfered with relationships and work. When stressed out, she becomes very impulsive, feels empty, thinks of suicide, and makes multiple cuts on her forearms. Which of the following most likely contributed to her problems?
Notes: 1=A brain infection in childhood; 2=Abusive or neglecting parents; 3=Influence of bad friends in adulthood; 4=Lack of everyday rest and relaxation; 5=Not enough vitamins and minerals in the diet

ElementDescription: Which of the following is a common symptom of obsessive-compulsive disorder?
Notes: 1=Fear of social situations; 2=Intrusive thoughts or impulses; 3=Ongoing concern about having a panic attack; 4=Overeating and weight gain; 5=Thinking that others are watching or following

ElementDescription: A woman brings her 16-year-old son to a psychologist for an evaluation of failing grades. In order for the psychologist to ensure that this young man does not have intellectual disability, which of the following questions is he likely to ask?
Notes: 1=Did any of his family members have learning problems? 2=Do his classmates make fun of him? 3=Does he also have unusual beliefs? 4=When did his learning difficulties first begin? 5=Which class does he currently like the least?

ElementDescription: A 35-year-old woman has been court-ordered to see a psychologist for problems stemming from her alcohol and cocaine use. Which of the following is the psychologist likely to be working to change?
Notes: 1=Avoidance; 2=Denial; 3=Pessimism; 4=Violence; 5=Withdrawal

ElementDescription: A woman who has borderline personality disorder frequently becomes suicidal due to an ongoing fear. Which of the following is she most likely subconsciously afraid of?
Notes: 1=Abandonment; 2=Being followed; 3=Contamination; 4=Gaining weight; 5=Growing old

ElementDescription: People who have posttraumatic stress disorder are at highest risk for also having which of the following?
Notes: 1=Alcohol abuse; 2=Bipolar disorder; 3=Early-onset dementia; 4=Intellectual disability; 5=Schizophrenia

ElementDescription: A 13-year-old girl with severe intellectual disability has been followed by a child psychiatrist for ten years. She has never taken medications, but the
Notes: 1=It is now clear that the intellectual disability is not getting better without medicine; 2=Medicine may help with problems that are worsening, such as behavior outbursts; 3=School demands are now greater and she will need medicine to help with learning; 4=She is now an adolescent and can take psychiatric medications; 5=The intellectual disability has advanced from a moderate to severe level

ElementDescription: Delirium and seizures may occur during withdrawal from heavy, long-term use of which of the following substances?
Notes: 1=Alcohol; 2=Inhalants; 3=Marihuana; 4=Mushrooms; 5=Narcotics

ElementDescription: Which of the following is a common reason why a woman with schizophrenia might not regularly take her medicine?
Notes: 1=Her anxiety disorder makes her to nervous; 2=She does not recognize that she has an illness; 3=She needs psychotherapy instead of medicine; 4=The medicine is addictive and she is afraid to take it; 5=The pills are very large and hard to swallow

ElementDescription: Most people in treatment for depression are treated by which of the following?
Notes: 1=Case managers; 2=Family therapists; 3=Primary care physicians; 4=Psychiatrists in hospitals; 5=The clergy

ElementDescription: Which of the following best describes the treatment approach for developmental disabilities?
Notes: 1=Combination of medications to control behavior; 2=Combination of special supports and services; 3=Long-term institutional care; 4=Long-term psychotherapy; 5=Supervision by a life coach

ElementDescription: A mother and father meet with a mental health professional for three sessions over the course of a month after their 25-year-old son committed suicide. Which of the following is the most likely reason for their meetings?
Notes: 1=To assess for any mental illnesses; 2=To attempts to determine what the warning signs had been; 3=To begin processing their grief and loss; 4=To determine what could have been done to prevent the suicide; 5=To make a diagnosis of their son's likely mental illness

ElementDescription: Which of the following is likely a cause of attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder in children?
Notes: 1=An inherited risk; 2=Certain medications; 3=Eating too much sugar; 4=Not getting enough sleep; 5=Poor control over classrooms

ElementDescription: Which of the following is the most common long-term course of dementia?
Notes: 1=Improvement; 2=Paralysis; 3=Progression; 4=Remission; 5=Stabilization

ElementDescription: A woman is diagnosed with depression by her doctor during a hospital stay for asthma. Her doctor was most likely prompted to screen for depression because the woman has which of the following?
Notes: 1=A long history of smoking cigarettes; 2=Family members with depression; 3=Little improvement from asthma treatment; 4=Poor understanding of her condition; 5=Three children under the age of 18

ElementDescription: Which of the following is a common sign of mania?
Notes: 1=Becoming forgetful; 2=Being more talkative than usual; 3=Experiencing repeated flashbacks; 4=Feeling helpless or hopeless; 5=Having anxiety attacks

ElementDescription: A 25-year-old woman receives a number of services through the local mental health system and social agencies, including someone to visit her at home to help with hygiene and cooking, a job coach, a psychiatrist, and a neurologist. Which of the following conditions does she most likely have?
Notes: 1=Adjustment disorder; 2=Dementia; 3=Developmental disability; 4=Drug addiction; 5=Personality disorder

ElementDescription: An 8-year-old boy is diagnosed as having depression by a psychiatrist. The psychiatrist tells the boy's parents that sometimes depression in children appears different from depression in adults. Which of the following is an example of what the psychiatrist is describing?
Notes: 1=Having high energy rather than low energy; 2=Hearing voices rather than feeling hopeless; 3=High self-esteem rather than low self-esteem; 4=Homicidal thoughts rather than suicidal thoughts; 5=Irritability rather than feeling depressed

ElementDescription: Which of the following best describes an addiction?
Notes: 1=Family members are often unaware that any problem exists; 2=It is a chronic disorder requiring many treatment approaches; 3=It is a short-term behavioral problem usually tied to a major life event; 4=Recovery is rare when a psychiatric disorder is also present; 5=Treatment usually includes a medicine that is taken long-term

ElementDescription: Which of the following is most likely to increase one's risk for depression?
Notes: 1=Being abused as a child; 2=Eating a high-fat diet; 3=Moving to a new residence; 4=Not relaxing enough; 5=Working past the age of 65

ElementDescription: A man at an airport is talking and laughing very loudly, passing out twenty-dollar bills, and telling people he plans to fly around the world to attend sixteen diplomatic meetings. He likely has which of the following?
Notes: 1=Alcohol abuse; 2=Delirium; 3=Mania; 4=Obsessions; 5=Pathological lying

ElementDescription: People who have personality disorders usually have these problems during which of the following life stages?
Notes: 1=Adolescence and adulthood; 2=After major life events; 3=Childhood and adolescence; 4=Older adulthood; 5=When going through puberty

ElementDescription: A man has been having episodes of chest pain, hyperventilation, and extreme anxiety during the past few months. He is afraid that he will die of a heart attack during one of these episodes. He has seen several doctors, who assure him that his heart is healthy. He now avoids driving because it seems to trigger these attacks. Which of the following treatments would be most helpful?
Notes: 1=Counseling; 2=Herbal supplements; 3=Mood stabilizer; 4=Physical therapy; 5=Regular exercise

ElementDescription: Which of the following is a common sign of oppositional defiant disorder in childhood?
Notes: 1=Arguing with teachers; 2=Being teased at school; 3=Crying at doctors' offices; 4=Feeling depressed; 5=Not wanting to get on the school bus

ElementDescription: The sum of all 33 items in the Knowledge scale
It is helpful for many people with serious mental illnesses to be part of a normal community
Notes: 5=Strongly agree; 4=Agree; 3=Not sure but probably agree; 2=Not sure but probably disagree; 1=Disagree; 0=Strongly disagree

ElementDescription: Most patients in psychiatric hospitals are not dangerous
Notes: 5=Strongly agree; 4=Agree; 3=Not sure but probably agree; 2=Not sure but probably disagree; 1=Disagree; 0=Strongly disagree

ElementDescription: Having people with mental illnesses living within residential neighborhoods might be good therapy but the risks to residents are too great
Notes: 0=Strongly agree; 1=Agree; 2=Not sure but probably agree; 3=Not sure but probably disagree; 4=Disagree; 5=Strongly Disagree

ElementDescription: Psychiatric medicines help people with serious mental illnesses move beyond their symptoms
Notes: 5=Strongly agree; 4=Agree; 3=Not sure but probably agree; 2=Not sure but probably disagree; 1=Disagree; 0=Strongly disagree

ElementDescription: Psychotherapy is needed because people with mental illnesses are often dangerous
Notes: 0=Strongly agree; 1=Agree; 2=Not sure but probably agree; 3=Not sure but probably disagree; 4=Disagree; 5=Strongly Disagree

ElementDescription: People with mental illnesses let their emotions control them; normal people think things out
Notes: 0=Strongly agree; 1=Agree; 2=Not sure but probably agree; 3=Not sure but probably disagree; 4=Disagree; 5=Strongly Disagree

ElementDescription: Locating mental health services in residential neighborhoods does not endanger local residents
Notes: 5=Strongly agree; 4=Agree; 3=Not sure but probably agree; 2=Not sure but probably disagree; 1=Disagree; 0=Strongly disagree

ElementDescription: Being in psychotherapy indicates one is trying to succeed in life
Notes: 5=Strongly agree; 4=Agree; 3=Not sure but probably agree; 2=Not sure but probably disagree; 1=Disagree; 0=Strongly disagree

ElementDescription: Although some people with serious mental illnesses seem alright, it is dangerous to forget that they have a mental illness
Notes: 0=Strongly agree; 1=Agree; 2=Not sure but probably agree; 3=Not sure but probably disagree; 4=Disagree; 5=Strongly Disagree

ElementDescription: People who were once patients in psychiatric hospitals are no more dangerous than the average citizen
Notes: 5=Strongly agree; 4=Agree; 3=Not sure but probably agree; 2=Not sure but probably disagree; 1=Disagree; 0=Strongly disagree

ElementDescription: Mental health facilities should be kept out of residential neighborhoods
Notes: 0=Strongly agree; 1=Agree; 2=Not sure but probably agree; 3=Not sure but probably disagree; 4=Disagree; 5=Strongly Disagree

ElementDescription: Psychotherapy is a useful form of treatment for people with mental illnesses
Notes: 5=Strongly agree; 4=Agree; 3=Not sure but probably agree; 2=Not sure but probably disagree; 1=Disagree; 0=Strongly disagree

ElementDescription: People with serious mental illnesses go to day treatment programs because they are usually unwilling to work
Notes: 0=Strongly agree; 1=Agree; 2=Not sure but probably agree; 3=Not sure but probably disagree; 4=Disagree; 5=Strongly Disagree

ElementDescription: People who are successful in their work seldom develop mental illnesses
Notes: 0=Strongly agree; 1=Agree; 2=Not sure but probably agree; 3=Not sure but probably disagree; 4=Disagree; 5=Strongly Disagree

ElementDescription: More tax money should be spent in the care and treatment of people with serious mental illnesses
Notes: 5=Strongly agree; 4=Agree; 3=Not sure but probably agree; 2=Not sure but probably disagree; 1=Disagree; 0=Strongly disagree
